                        <h6 id="/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagram/prop/@ns" class="toc6 head">@ns</h6>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagram/prop/@ns">/system-security-plan/system-characteristics/data-flow/diagram/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                  </section>

                     --&gt;

                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                           <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                        </div>
                     </details>

                  <section class="xml-element">

                        </div>

                        --&gt;

                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                 resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                 containing the link.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                  </section>

                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the

                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                     </div>

                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                     </details>

                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

                        <div class="remarks">

                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                     <div class="remarks">

                           that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                        <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment

                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>

                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                     </div>
                  </details>

                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>

                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>

                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>

                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                     </div>
                  </details>

               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">

                     </div>

                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>

            <div class="header">

               <h3 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component" class="toc3 head">component</h3>
            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">element Component</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                  <p>An element </p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">A defined component that can be part of an implemented system.</p>
               
               --&gt;      
               
               --&gt;      
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>Components may be products, services, application programming interface (APIs), policies,
                        processes, plans, guidance, standards, or other tangible items that enable security
                        and/or privacy.</p>
                     <p>The <code>type</code> indicates which of these component types is represented.</p>
                     <p>When defining a <code>service</code> component where are relationship to other components is known, one or more <code>link</code> entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific
                        component identifier(s) that provide and use the service respectively.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>

            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component/prop" class="toc4 head">prop</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component/prop">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component/prop</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">

                  </div>

                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Name</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or

               </section>

                  </div>

                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Universally Unique Identifier</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      </div>
               </section>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props/ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                     <h5 id="/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component/prop/@ns" class="toc5 head">@ns</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component/prop/@ns">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/component/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/components/props/value"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to

                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>

                        <p>An element </p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                        qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                        may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>

                     </details>

                        <div class="obj-matrix">

                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                           <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

                        --&gt;

                           <summary>Remarks</summary>

                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                                 containing the link.</p>

                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>

                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                           <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                 resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                 containing the link.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-item/implemented-component/prop">/system-security-plan/system-implementation/inventory-item/implemented-component/prop</a> in the element map.</p>

                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An element </p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                        qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                        may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>

                     </div>

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

                        <div class="remarks">

                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>

                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                                 containing the link.</p>

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which

                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

                              <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                              associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>

                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed

                                    to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                 <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                    that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                 <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                    "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                 <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                    resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                    containing the link.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>

            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop" class="toc4 head">prop</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">

                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Name</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a></p>

                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop/@uuid">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop/@uuid</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">

               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/props/ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                     <h5 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop/@ns" class="toc5 head">@ns</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop/@ns">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>

                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment

                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                     </div>
                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                        qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                        may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>

                     </details>

                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                           <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>

                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                 resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                 containing the link.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/@uuid">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/@uuid</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Control Statement Reference Universally Unique Identifier</p>

               <section class="xml-element">

                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/prop">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/prop</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An element </p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                        qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                        may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Name</p>

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                           document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                           of the document.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;

                  </section>
                  <section class="xml-element">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/props/ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                        <h6 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/prop/@ns" class="toc6 head">@ns</h6>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/prop/@ns">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                  </section>

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;

                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>

                     <div class="header">

                        <h6 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/prop" class="toc6 head">prop</h6>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/prop">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/prop</a> in the element map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An element </p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

                           </div>

                              quality of the property's containing object.</p>

                           </div>

                     <section class="xml-element">
                        <div class="header">
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/by-components/props/ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                           <h7 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/prop/@ns" class="toc7 head">@ns</h7>
                        </div>
                        <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/prop/@ns">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                              <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                              associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                           
                           --&gt;      
                           
                           --&gt;      
                           
                           --&gt;      
                           
                           --&gt;      
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                    names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                    with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                 <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                    to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                 <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                     </section>

                  <section class="xml-element">

                        </div>

                        --&gt;

                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                 a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

                                 <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                    that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                 <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                    "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                 <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                    resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                    containing the link.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                     </section>

                     <section class="xml-element">
                        <div class="header">
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/by-components/export/props"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                           <h7 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/prop" class="toc7 head">prop</h7>
                        </div>
                        <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/prop">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/prop</a> in the element map.</p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An element </p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           
                           --&gt;      
                           
                           --&gt;      
                           
                           --&gt;      
                           
                           --&gt;      
                           
                           --&gt;      
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <section class="xml-element">
                           <div class="header">

                           </div>

                           <div class="obj-desc">

                              </div>

                                 quality of the property's containing object.</p>

                        </section>
                        <section class="xml-element">
                           <div class="header">
                              <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/by-components/export/props/uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                              <h8 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/prop/@uuid" class="toc8 head">@uuid</h8>
                           </div>
                           <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/prop/@uuid">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/prop/@uuid</a> in the element map.</p>
                           <div class="obj-desc">
                              <div class="obj-matrix">
                                 <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Universally Unique Identifier</p>
                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                                 <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a></p>
                              </div>
                              <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                                 document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                                 of the document.</p>
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              
                              --&gt;      </div>
                        </section>
                        <section class="xml-element">
                           <div class="header">
                              <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirements/statements/by-components/export/props/ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                              <h8 id="/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/prop/@ns" class="toc8 head">@ns</h8>
                           </div>
                           <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/prop/@ns">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                           <div class="obj-desc">
                              <div class="obj-matrix">
                                 <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                                 <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                              </div>
                              <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                                 associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                       names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                       with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                    <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                       to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                    <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>
                        </section>

                        <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/link">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/link</a> in the element map.</p>

                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An element </p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>

                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                    a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                                 <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <section class="xml-element">
                           <div class="header">

                           </div>
                           <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/link/@href">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/link/@href</a> in the element map.</p>

                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                                 <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
                              </div>

                              --&gt;      
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              
                              --&gt;      
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                       that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                    <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                       "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                    <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                       resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                       containing the link.</p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>
                        </section>

                           <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/provided/description">/system-security-plan/control-implementation/implemented-requirement/statement/by-component/export/provided/description</a> in the element map.</p>
                           <div class="obj-desc">
                              <div class="obj-matrix">
                                 <p class="obj-name">element Provided Control Implementation Description</p>

                        <section class="xml-element">
